commit_message:
hyper-v: Adds support for ISO images

ISO is added as a supported format in imagecache, meaning that
ISOs can be attached to VMs. ISOs are attached the same way
VHD / VHDX disks are attached.

Co-Authored-By: Adelina Tuvenie <atuvenie@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Partially implements: blueprint hyper-v-boot-from-iso

Change-Id: I3704c2c391944351a5a9c58d08360db622e5c8bf

commit_message:
Adds CPUFeaturesField to ImageMetaProps

Certain images can request certain CPU features through the
image metadata properties (for example, an image can require the
'vmx' CPU feature in order to enable nested virtualization).

This commit defines the CPUFeature enumeration and the CPUFeaturesField,
and adds the 'hw_cpu_features' field to the ImageMetaProps object.

DocImpact: The glance-property-keys page of the cli-reference docs will
have to be updated to include details about the "hw_cpu_features" image
property and its possible values.

Change-Id: Id118764d77684d3387ac7c90150b8ad571d7a8f0
Partially-Implements: blueprint hyper-v-nested-virtualization

DocImpact: The compute-flavors page of the admin guide will

commit_message:
hyper-v: Adds support for VMs with nested virtualization

Nested virtualization is a new feature introduced in
Windows / Hyper-V Server 2016.

The nova Hyper-V Driver will enable nested virtualization for
an instance if the given instance flavor extra_specs
"hw:cpu_features" or the given instance image property
"hw_cpu_features" contains the CPU feature "vmx".

An instance with nested virtualization enabled, cannot have
dynamic memory.

DocImpact: The compute-flavors page of the admin guide will
have to be updated to include information about the "hw:cpu_features"
extra_specs.

Depends-On: I238161a8cd1d589a7d57fe9cf74b18b22679998c

Change-Id: Ie780dfc48abeabfd7a9319ce4fe66ba914a73988
Implements: blueprint hyper-v-nested-virtualization

commit_message:
[Generic driver] Fix incompatibility with novaclient

Novaclient has removed lots of proxies to other clients such as
'images' [1], 'networks' [2] and 'security_groups' [3].
So, fix incompatibilities the way we can work with old and
new novaclient versions.

[1] I2d9fd0243d42538bd1417a42357c17b09368d2a5
[2] I8c520100a0016eed3959619c71dae037ebd72939
[3] I6fa14f43d48f1e035ef54bd2d0078506f0c6d6e0

Change-Id: Id7383329b2491f76579f042cbed06585c2214815
Closes-Bug: #1691445
(cherry picked from commit 5d5666b10e57a94bcde06c8a296002175d935c7b)

FICON (Fibre Connection) is a Fibre-Channel FC-4 layer protocol. It is
used on mainframes to attach ECKD volumes via Fibre-Channel. While FICON
shares a common transport protocol with FCP, there are several
differences. ECKD volumes are addressed by a Control Unit and Unit
Address, rather than a LUN. Besides, different commands are required in
order to attach an ECKD volume to a hypervisor.

Implements: blueprint linux-ficon-support
Depends-On: I84726b577dc108ff748fb331812197651b4fbbac

commit_message:
Support FICON-attached ECKD volumes on System z

FICON (Fibre Connection) is a Fibre-Channel FC-4 layer protocol. It is
used on mainframes to attach ECKD volumes via Fibre-Channel. While FICON
shares a common transport protocol with FCP, there are several
differences. ECKD volumes are addressed by a Control Unit and Unit
Address, rather than a LUN. Besides, different commands are required in
order to attach an ECKD volume to a hypervisor.

Implements: blueprint linux-ficon-support
Depends-On: I84726b577dc108ff748fb331812197651b4fbbac
Change-Id: I69f4409d73d2c786e3a94a88b76d6e0386f9a999

commit_message:
Fix the port for Panko API in devstack

The port used for Panko in devstack is conflicts with Trove[1].
The 8777 port has been occupied by ceilometer. So set the panko
api port to 8977.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/devstack/plugin.sh#L61

Change-Id: If6621a6bd1c6a5486d85ee33ec0760c8bbe1f860
Closes-Bug: #1696613

With I468dbf5134947629f125504513703d6f2cdace59 each node has a
reference to the global state object.  This means it gets pickled into
the node-list, which is loaded for later calls.  There is no need to
reload the state.json it and pass it for later cmd_* calls, as the

commit_message:
Remove 'state' argument from later cmd_* calls

With I468dbf5134947629f125504513703d6f2cdace59 each node has a
reference to the global state object.  This means it gets pickled into
the node-list, which is loaded for later calls.  There is no need to
reload the state.json it and pass it for later cmd_* calls, as the
nodes can see it via the unpickled self.state

Change-Id: I9e2f8910f17599d92ee33e7df8e36d8ed4d44575

commit_message:
Adds tests for compute snapshots API

Adds compute API tests for create, delete, show, and list
snapshots. Also corrects max_microversion for compute/test_volume_rbac
to 2.38 and changes test class name to follow Patrole class naming
conventions (include min_microversion in class name).

Change-Id: Ie04dfa26f598a818dfc3d6eb440dec3e29c5b604
Closes-Bug: #1692173

revisions:
[{'number': 3, 'created': '2017-05-25 16:36:27.000000000', 'files': ['tools/fixup_stuff.sh', 'stackrc'], 'message': "Make use of Ubuntu Cloud Archive switchable

The trove development environment is typically a linux VM within which
openstack is installed, and trove launches guest vm's within that
environment. To make it possible for these vm's to launch in one human
lifetime, one must set vt/x and enable nested hypervisors to use with
kvm; qemu emulation will take way too long.

The new libvirtd (v2.5.0) in Ubuntu Cloud Archive doesn't handle
nested hypervisors well and if you use it, you end up with a guest
hanging on the GRUB line.

To enable that use-case, we provide ENABLE_UBUNTU_CLOUD_ARCHIVE which
the trove developer can set (to False) before running devstack.

Change-Id: Ia0265c67bb7d2a438575a03c0ddbf2d9c53266ed
Closes-Bug: #1689370
"}]
commit_message:
Make use of Ubuntu Cloud Archive switchable

The trove development environment is typically a linux VM within which
openstack is installed, and trove launches guest vm's within that
environment. To make it possible for these vm's to launch in one human
lifetime, one must set vt/x and enable nested hypervisors to use with
kvm; qemu emulation will take way too long.

The new libvirtd (v2.5.0) in Ubuntu Cloud Archive doesn't handle
nested hypervisors well and if you use it, you end up with a guest
hanging on the GRUB line.

To enable that use-case, we provide ENABLE_UBUNTU_CLOUD_ARCHIVE which
the trove developer can set (to False) before running devstack.

Change-Id: Ia0265c67bb7d2a438575a03c0ddbf2d9c53266ed
Closes-Bug: #1689370

commit_message:
PPC bootloader; install to boot partition

Using the newly exposed variables from the prior change, install the
ppc bootloader to the boot partition, not the underlying loopback
device.

Change-Id: I0918e8df8797d6dbabf7af618989ab7f79ee9580

subject: Pass all blockdevices to bootloader
revisions:
[{'number': 9, 'created': '2017-06-08 07:14:52.000000000', 'files': ['diskimage_builder/elements/bootloader/finalise.d/50-bootloader', 'diskimage_builder/lib/common-functions', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level1/partition.py', 'diskimage_builder/lib/disk-image-create', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/blockdevice.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level1/partitioning.py'], 'message': 'Pass all blockdevices to bootloader

Currently we only export "image-block-device" which is the loopback
device (/dev/loopX) for the underlying image.  This is the device we
install grub to (from inside the chroot ...)

This is ok for x86, but is insufficient for some platforms like PPC
which have a separate boot partition.  They do not want to install to
the loop device, but do things like dd special ELF files into special
boot partitions.

The first problem seems to be that in level1/partitioning.py we have a
whole bunch of different paths that either call partprobe on the loop
device, or kpartx.  We have _all_part_devices_exist() that gates the
kpartx for unknown reasons.  We have detach_loopback() that does not
seem to remove losetup created devices.  I don't think this does
cleanup if it uses kpartx correctly.  It is extremley unclear what's
going to be mapped where.

This moves to us *only* using kpartx to map the partitions of the loop
device.  We will *not* call partprobe and create the /dev/loopXpN
devices and will only have the devicemapper nodes kpartx creates.
This seems to be best.  Cleanup happens inside partitioning.py.
practice.  Deeper thinking about this, and more cleanup of the
variables will be welcome.

This adds "image-block-devices" (note the extra "s") which exports all
the block devices with name and path.  This is in a string format that
can be eval'd to an array (you can't export arrays).

This is then used in a follow-on
(I0918e8df8797d6dbabf7af618989ab7f79ee9580) to pick the right
partition on PPC.

Change-Id: If8e33106b4104da2d56d7941ce96ffcb014907bc
'}]
commit_message:
Pass all blockdevices to bootloader

Currently we only export "image-block-device" which is the loopback
device (/dev/loopX) for the underlying image.  This is the device we
install grub to (from inside the chroot ...)

This is ok for x86, but is insufficient for some platforms like PPC
which have a separate boot partition.  They do not want to install to
the loop device, but do things like dd special ELF files into special
boot partitions.

The first problem seems to be that in level1/partitioning.py we have a
whole bunch of different paths that either call partprobe on the loop
device, or kpartx.  We have _all_part_devices_exist() that gates the
kpartx for unknown reasons.  We have detach_loopback() that does not
seem to remove losetup created devices.  I don't think this does
cleanup if it uses kpartx correctly.  It is extremley unclear what's
going to be mapped where.

This moves to us *only* using kpartx to map the partitions of the loop
device.  We will *not* call partprobe and create the /dev/loopXpN
devices and will only have the devicemapper nodes kpartx creates.
This seems to be best.  Cleanup happens inside partitioning.py.
practice.  Deeper thinking about this, and more cleanup of the
variables will be welcome.

This adds "image-block-devices" (note the extra "s") which exports all
the block devices with name and path.  This is in a string format that
can be eval'd to an array (you can't export arrays).

This is then used in a follow-on
(I0918e8df8797d6dbabf7af618989ab7f79ee9580) to pick the right
partition on PPC.

Change-Id: If8e33106b4104da2d56d7941ce96ffcb014907bc

subject: Move rollback into NodeBase object
revisions:
[{'number': 18, 'created': '2017-06-08 07:14:52.000000000', 'files': ['diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/plugin/test_a.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/test_mount_order.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/plugin.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/plugin/test_b.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level3/mount.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/test_state.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level0/localloop.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/config/rollback.yaml', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level2/mkfs.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level1/partition.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level4/fstab.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/blockdevice.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/level1/partitioning.py'], 'message': 'Move rollback into NodeBase object

Currently we pass a reference to a global "rollback" list to create()
to keep rollback functions.  Other nodes don't need to know about
global rollback state, and by passing by reference we're giving them
the chance to mess it up for everyone else.

Add a "add_rollback()" function in NodeBase for create() calls to
register rollback calls within themselves.  As they hit rollback
points they can add a new entry.  lambda v arguments is much of a
muchness -- but this is similar to the standard atexit() call so with
go with that pattern.  A new "rollback()" call is added that the
driver will invoke on each node as it works its way backwards in case
of failure.

On error, nodes will have rollback() called in reverse order (which
then calls registered rollbacks in reverse order).

A unit test is added to test rollback behaviour

Change-Id: I65214e72c7ef607dd08f750a6d32a0b10fe97ac3
'}]
commit_message:
Move rollback into NodeBase object

Currently we pass a reference to a global "rollback" list to create()
to keep rollback functions.  Other nodes don't need to know about
global rollback state, and by passing by reference we're giving them
the chance to mess it up for everyone else.

Add a "add_rollback()" function in NodeBase for create() calls to
register rollback calls within themselves.  As they hit rollback
points they can add a new entry.  lambda v arguments is much of a
muchness -- but this is similar to the standard atexit() call so with
go with that pattern.  A new "rollback()" call is added that the
driver will invoke on each node as it works its way backwards in case
of failure.

On error, nodes will have rollback() called in reverse order (which
then calls registered rollbacks in reverse order).

A unit test is added to test rollback behaviour

Change-Id: I65214e72c7ef607dd08f750a6d32a0b10fe97ac3

subject: Move global mount tracking into state
revisions:
[{'number': 15, 'created': '2017-06-08 07:14:52.000000000', 'files': ['diskimage_builder/block_device/level3/mount.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/test_config.py'], 'message': "Move global mount tracking into state

Keep track of the mount-point ordering in a state variable, rather
than a global.  This path is tested by existing unit tests.

Note a prior change inserted the MountNode objects directly into a
list in self.state, which makes sorting quite easy as it can just
implement __lt__.  Unfortunately we still json dump the state, and
thus we can't have aribtrary objects in it (future work may be to
check keys inserted into the status object...).  So we have to do a
bit of wrangling with tuple lists and comparision functions here, but
it's not too bad.

Change-Id: I0c51e0c53c4efdb7a65ab0efe09a6780cb1affa8
"}]
commit_message:
Move global mount tracking into state

Keep track of the mount-point ordering in a state variable, rather
than a global.  This path is tested by existing unit tests.

Note a prior change inserted the MountNode objects directly into a
list in self.state, which makes sorting quite easy as it can just
implement __lt__.  Unfortunately we still json dump the state, and
thus we can't have aribtrary objects in it (future work may be to
check keys inserted into the status object...).  So we have to do a
bit of wrangling with tuple lists and comparision functions here, but
it's not too bad.

Change-Id: I0c51e0c53c4efdb7a65ab0efe09a6780cb1affa8

commit_message:
Use global state to check for duplicate fs labels

As we add file-systems, add them to global state and check the labels
are uniqiue.  Add a unit test and remove the old global value.

Bonus fixup to the length check, and a test for that too.

Change-Id: I0f5a96f687c92e000afc9c98a26c49c4b1d3f28d

commit_message:
tests: use devstack-gate to deploy dstat for functional/fullstack

This should help with a gate failure where IPV4_ADDRS_SAFE_TO_USE would
not be honoured by devstack, rendering a job failed on a particular
cloud (like citycloud), like:

'Could not determine host ip address. See local.conf for suggestions on
setting HOST_IP.'

Closes-Bug: #1693689
Change-Id: Iee7cc4c129e6e9eab91107fda92f66c5379d6f95

commit_message:
Use rootwrap for fullstack test runner

We plan to switch to devstack-gate for fullstack job, and it revokes
direct sudo calls before executing tests, so we can't rely on sudo
working anymore.

This also moves functional-testing.filters to a more generic filename
(testing.filters) because the filters are now deployed and used by
fullstack target too.

Related-Bug: #1557168
Related-Bug: #1693689

Change-Id: I1718ea51836adbb8ef8dea79822a722dcf111127

commit_message:
VMAX driver - sizing changes due to VMAX cylinder size

Changes have been made to the way in which volume sizes are determined
so that now cylinder to size relationship is taken into consideration
so that volumes do not exceed their specified size. Array/SLO capacity
calculations remain as is, they are absolute in their calculations.
Methods were tidied up to reflect their return type and size measurement
bytes instead of bits).

Change-Id: I01a43c794f331b1e2d81e21116ecfc2826b1bb53
Closes-Bug: #1690359

Making the global state reference a defined part of the node makes
some parts of the block device processing easier and removes the need
for other global values.

The state is passed to PluginNodeBase.__init__() and expected to be
passed into all nodes as they are created.  NodeBase.__init__() is
updated with the new paramater 'state'.

The parameter is removed from the create() call as nodes can simply

This is similar to 1cdc8b20373c5d582ea928cfd7334469ff36dbce, except it
is based on I68840594a34af28d41d9522addcfd830bd203b97 which loads the

Change-Id: I468dbf5134947629f125504513703d6f2cdace59

commit_message:
Add state to NodeBase class

Making the global state reference a defined part of the node makes
some parts of the block device processing easier and removes the need
for other global values.

The state is passed to PluginNodeBase.__init__() and expected to be
passed into all nodes as they are created.  NodeBase.__init__() is
updated with the new paramater 'state'.

The parameter is removed from the create() call as nodes can simply
reference it at any point as "self.state".

This is similar to 1cdc8b20373c5d582ea928cfd7334469ff36dbce, except it
is based on I68840594a34af28d41d9522addcfd830bd203b97 which loads the
node-list from pickled state for later cmd_* calls.  Thus we only
build the state *once*, at cmd_create() time as we build the node
list.

Change-Id: I468dbf5134947629f125504513703d6f2cdace59

subject: Use picked nodes for later cmd_* calls
revisions:
[{'number': 12, 'created': '2017-06-08 07:14:52.000000000', 'files': ['diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/test_state.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/plugin/test_a.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/blockdevice.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/plugin/test_b.py'], 'message': 'Use picked nodes for later cmd_* calls

Currently the later cmd_* calls -- umount, cleanup, delete -- all
recreate the node graph by parsing the config file using
create_graph()

There is some need, however, to have a sense of global state when
building the node list.  The problem is, this is a one time operation
-- we do not want to rebuild that state for these later calls (see the
"loaded" checks in proposed
Ic3b805f9258128d5233b21ff25579c03487c7fcc).

An insight here seems to be that these cmd_* calls do not actually
want to re-parse the configuration file and rebuild the node list;
they just want to walk the node list in reverse with the state as
provided after cmd_create().

So, rather than re-creating the node list, we might as well just
pickle it, save it to disk along side the state dictionary dump and
reload it for cmd_*.

After this, I think we can safely have PluginBase.__init__() be passed
the state.  We will now know that this will only be called once,
during initial creation.

Change-Id: I68840594a34af28d41d9522addcfd830bd203b97
'}]
commit_message:
Use picked nodes for later cmd_* calls

Currently the later cmd_* calls -- umount, cleanup, delete -- all
recreate the node graph by parsing the config file using
create_graph()

There is some need, however, to have a sense of global state when
building the node list.  The problem is, this is a one time operation
-- we do not want to rebuild that state for these later calls (see the
"loaded" checks in proposed
Ic3b805f9258128d5233b21ff25579c03487c7fcc).

An insight here seems to be that these cmd_* calls do not actually
want to re-parse the configuration file and rebuild the node list;
they just want to walk the node list in reverse with the state as
provided after cmd_create().

So, rather than re-creating the node list, we might as well just
pickle it, save it to disk along side the state dictionary dump and
reload it for cmd_*.

After this, I think we can safely have PluginBase.__init__() be passed
the state.  We will now know that this will only be called once,
during initial creation.

Change-Id: I68840594a34af28d41d9522addcfd830bd203b97

[{'number': 7, 'created': '2017-06-06 06:01:10.000000000', 'files': ['roles/undercloud-deploy/tasks/configure-vbmc.yml', 'roles/undercloud-deploy/defaults/main.yml'], 'message': 'Support arbitrary nat network order

Previously the vbmc would use the address of the first network
defined in order to connect. By changing this to search for the
first network with an address and fall back to using the default
libvirt network address, networks can be re-ordered and re-named
as desired.

Default libvirt network support is added in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/406421/

Change-Id: Id4a298f91c75bcd0843648939c0a8da02b9f6a6c
'}]
commit_message:
Support arbitrary nat network order

Previously the vbmc would use the address of the first network
defined in order to connect. By changing this to search for the
first network with an address and fall back to using the default
libvirt network address, networks can be re-ordered and re-named
as desired.

Default libvirt network support is added in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/406421/

Change-Id: Id4a298f91c75bcd0843648939c0a8da02b9f6a6c

subject: Don't make image & loopdev functions static
revisions:
[{'number': 8, 'created': '2017-06-08 07:14:52.000000000', 'files': ['diskimage_builder/block_device/level0/localloop.py', 'diskimage_builder/block_device/tests/test_mbr.py'], 'message': 'Don't make image & loopdev functions static

You can't pickle a static method reference which complicates being
able to save the node graph when the "rollback" call-back wants to
hold references to these functions.  The outer module (localoop.py) is
small anyway, so from an organisation point of view the difference is
minimal.  Since these are really only called with parameters from the
containing class, they could be class methods with no parameters, at
the small expense of having to fiddle the mbr test-case a bit.

Change-Id: I6f9592a4295abe1b41294b79828bc2f3c2da01c6
'}]
commit_message:
Don't make image & loopdev functions static

You can't pickle a static method reference which complicates being
able to save the node graph when the "rollback" call-back wants to
hold references to these functions.  The outer module (localoop.py) is
small anyway, so from an organisation point of view the difference is
minimal.  Since these are really only called with parameters from the
containing class, they could be class methods with no parameters, at
the small expense of having to fiddle the mbr test-case a bit.

Change-Id: I6f9592a4295abe1b41294b79828bc2f3c2da01c6

commit_message:
Replace SortedDict with OrderedDict and fixing Python 3.5 test

Starting with Django 1.9 SortedDict has been removed completely,
and this is currently blocking the gate.

This patch replaces SortedDict with the python native OrderedDict.

Depends-On: Iebca15ae962a1aa0825c6ba6d482206531726696
Change-Id: Ia7955ac9b9e549a88839487130c416036bb27c1a

        Problem:
        Received HTTP 500 Internal Server Error when using PATCH or
	PUT in query without specifying alarm definition id.

        Solution:
        Modified on_patch() and on_put() so that if alarm definition id
	is not specified, query response will be HTTP 422 Unprocessible Entity.

Change-Id: I0a212f09cb76d1b4db6f129fe9ca94ec1fc274df
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed endpoint required parameters

        Problem:
        Received HTTP 500 Internal Server Error when using PATCH or
	PUT in query without specifying alarm definition id.

        Solution:
        Modified on_patch() and on_put() so that if alarm definition id
	is not specified, query response will be HTTP 422 Unprocessible Entity.

Change-Id: I0a212f09cb76d1b4db6f129fe9ca94ec1fc274df

subject: Add block/always to tempest result file tasks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-08 15:24:17.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/tempest_run.yml'], 'message': 'Add block/always to tempest result file tasks

The tempest result files should always be generated, regardless of
a tempest test failure or not. With out the block/always statement,
the tempest result files would only generate if the tempest tests
succeeded. This commit adds the block/always around the result file
tasks so that they are generated when the tempest tests fail.

Change-Id: I6698d52a7209005449fdb69a35eeaad763c59da9
'}]
commit_message:
Add block/always to tempest result file tasks

The tempest result files should always be generated, regardless of
a tempest test failure or not. With out the block/always statement,
the tempest result files would only generate if the tempest tests
succeeded. This commit adds the block/always around the result file
tasks so that they are generated when the tempest tests fail.

Change-Id: I6698d52a7209005449fdb69a35eeaad763c59da9

commit_message:
Update vars to match latest keepalived role

While the user interface is retro-compatible, it's probably better
to adapt our vars and examples to show what's the future gonna be.

Change-Id: Ic242f98d775ccd176e69251e4734075bbbb01146

subject: Fix Python 3 bytes vs strings differences
revisions:
[{'number': 5, 'created': '2017-06-08 18:42:07.000000000', 'files': ['osa_toolkit/filesystem.py', 'tests/test_inventory.py'], 'message': 'Fix Python 3 bytes vs strings differences

Writing files was done fairly naively with our Python 2 code - this
change introduces explicit ASCII encoding when writing files.

Change-Id: I93c9fa4ba2fd8af9c9bf9424adaec602dbdca5f0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Python 3 bytes vs strings differences

Writing files was done fairly naively with our Python 2 code - this
change introduces explicit ASCII encoding when writing files.

Change-Id: I93c9fa4ba2fd8af9c9bf9424adaec602dbdca5f0

subject: Fix Python 3 dictionary incompatibilities
revisions:
[{'number': 5, 'created': '2017-06-08 18:41:35.000000000', 'files': ['tests/test_inventory.py', 'osa_toolkit/generate.py'], 'message': 'Fix Python 3 dictionary incompatibilities

There were two instances of abusing old Python 2 behaviors around
dictionary keys that Python 3 no longer allows. These are both fixed.

Change-Id: I5865ee3becf52fca590a1c0c897bcd968210ac9d
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Python 3 dictionary incompatibilities

There were two instances of abusing old Python 2 behaviors around
dictionary keys that Python 3 no longer allows. These are both fixed.

Change-Id: I5865ee3becf52fca590a1c0c897bcd968210ac9d

subject: Revert role pin for further Pike development
revisions:
[{'number': 5, 'created': '2017-06-08 17:15:22.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/defaults/repo_packages/openstack_services.yml', 'ansible-role-requirements.yml'], 'message': "Revert role pin for further Pike development

Now that Pike-2 has been released, we can continue to
develop against the master branches of all the roles.

Some service SHA's are also updated due to the
keystonemiddleware switch from pycrypto to cryptography.

Change-Id: Ieb103093b7cd8fbf8b8f1acffd7b07efe70ab5d9
"}]
commit_message:
Revert role pin for further Pike development

Now that Pike-2 has been released, we can continue to
develop against the master branches of all the roles.

Some service SHA's are also updated due to the
keystonemiddleware switch from pycrypto to cryptography.

Change-Id: Ieb103093b7cd8fbf8b8f1acffd7b07efe70ab5d9

[{'number': 15, 'created': '2017-01-26 07:01:50.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/cmd/security_group_migration/__init__.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/rpc.py', 'neutron/cmd/security_group_migration/ovs.py', 'neutron/cmd/security_group_migration/__init__.py', 'neutron/common/utils.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/base_type_tunnel.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/type_tunnel.py', 'neutron/cmd/security_group_migration/main.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py', 'neutron/cmd/security_group_migration/domxml.py', 'neutron/tests/functional/cmd/security_group_migration/__init__.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/test_plugin.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/cmd/security_group_migration/test_domxml.py', 'neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/common/test_ovs_lib.py', 'neutron/tests/functional/cmd/security_group_migration/ovs.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/test_rpc.py', 'neutron/tests/common/net_helpers.py', 'setup.cfg'], 'message': "ovs fw migration from iptables

With the introduction of ovs fw, there's an odd state where old
instances are using iptables, but new instances are using ovs fw. This
patch proposes a mechanism to migrate iptables-based instances to ovs
fw.

It is expected for, during the migration run, that the nova-compute
process will be disabled ('nova service-disable') and not running, in
order to avoid race conditions that might stem from running the
migration on a port concurrently to some nova action on the instance.

The code doesn't use python-libvirt as, for some reason, the code
crashed locally (segmentation fault) during development. I'd rather
merge it as is and work during Pike to migrate it to python-libvirt.

An alternative for this patch was using 'nova interface-detach' and
'nova interface-attach'. Such an alternative is less optimal than this
solution in the sense that it necessitate a downtime for the guest it
self (actual device removal) while the port is detached (whereas this
solution just re-plugs the interface, causing a much negligible
downtime).

Closes-Bug: #1652071
Change-Id: I34be675e78a98127e184a5efc6cddd72e7a18e4a
"}]
commit_message:
ovs fw migration from iptables

With the introduction of ovs fw, there's an odd state where old
instances are using iptables, but new instances are using ovs fw. This
patch proposes a mechanism to migrate iptables-based instances to ovs
fw.

It is expected for, during the migration run, that the nova-compute
process will be disabled ('nova service-disable') and not running, in
order to avoid race conditions that might stem from running the
migration on a port concurrently to some nova action on the instance.

The code doesn't use python-libvirt as, for some reason, the code
crashed locally (segmentation fault) during development. I'd rather
merge it as is and work during Pike to migrate it to python-libvirt.

An alternative for this patch was using 'nova interface-detach' and
'nova interface-attach'. Such an alternative is less optimal than this
solution in the sense that it necessitate a downtime for the guest it
self (actual device removal) while the port is detached (whereas this
solution just re-plugs the interface, causing a much negligible
downtime).

Closes-Bug: #1652071
Change-Id: I34be675e78a98127e184a5efc6cddd72e7a18e4a

subject: Simplify multi arch repo build
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-08 08:31:35.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/repo-build.yml'], 'message': 'Simplify multi arch repo build

When using repo_build, we were creating groups by architecture,
but then did complex operations to see if they were using
different os versions.

This commit simplifies this, by creating groups depending on both
arch and distribution: It improves readability, but also
fixes the issues where no group was previously created for
multiple architectures.

Change-Id: I36c3033b8a932a81d98bd85d6cfb738e77147192
Closes-Bug: #1694265
(cherry picked from commit e7800cef933938b103fd33bb93590e18e93c29d7)
'}]
commit_message:
Simplify multi arch repo build

When using repo_build, we were creating groups by architecture,
but then did complex operations to see if they were using
different os versions.

This commit simplifies this, by creating groups depending on both
arch and distribution: It improves readability, but also
fixes the issues where no group was previously created for
multiple architectures.

Change-Id: I36c3033b8a932a81d98bd85d6cfb738e77147192
Closes-Bug: #1694265
(cherry picked from commit e7800cef933938b103fd33bb93590e18e93c29d7)

commit_message:
Fix the default port for Panko API

The port used for Panko in the puppet module is conflicts with Trove[1].
According to the official documentation[2] this should be 8777. The
8777 port has been occupied by ceilometer. So set the panko api port to
8977.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/etc/apache2/trove#L20
[2]https://docs.openstack.org/developer/panko/install/manual.html#installing-the-api-server

Change-Id: I53b286d1d6466b574fdb286cc45f3138f96dff59
Closes-Bug: #1691283

commit_message:
Optimise the distro package installation

In order to optimise the distro package installation
process the list of packages is passed directly to
the package module instead of using a loop.

The package installation tasks are also made to be
more consistent.

Change-Id: I3f2fa4a0ff5f5387fe888cb2259585f00d0291e3

commit_message:
Move rebuild notification tests into separate method

The current rebuild testing in test_instance_action changes the image
used by the instance, therefore the actions tested in
test_instance_action had to be in specific order as testing rebuild
also changes the output json.

The rebuild test was moved from test_instance_action to its own method,
and now all the actions in test_instance_actions keeps the instance in
the same state.

Change-Id: Id0a7aaf8575d69deb89d3842b54fc23ee05b2153
Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-pike

commit_message:
Fix device metadata service version check for multiple cells

This makes the service version check for device metadata support use the
new cross-cell helper. Without this, we could incorrectly determine that
everything is new when it is not.

Change-Id: I207dd91c447d7b0da392d333a2806a1a10e1451c
Closes-Bug: #1695993

subject: Optimise the distro package installation
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-08 16:00:29.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/memcached_install.yml', 'defaults/main.yml', 'vars/main.yml'], 'message': 'Optimise the distro package installation

In order to optimise the distro package installation
process the list of packages to install is prepared
for the host, then installed by passing the package
task the full list instead of using a loop.

The package lists in defaults are removed as it is
undesirable to make it easy to override these lists.
This is not provided for in any other roles.

Change-Id: I71307d2a808fdc0f76e376a84651dad86b3f8b69
'}]
commit_message:
Optimise the distro package installation

In order to optimise the distro package installation
process the list of packages to install is prepared
for the host, then installed by passing the package
task the full list instead of using a loop.

The package lists in defaults are removed as it is
undesirable to make it easy to override these lists.
This is not provided for in any other roles.

Change-Id: I71307d2a808fdc0f76e376a84651dad86b3f8b69

commit_message:
Use charms.openstack charmhelpers test_mocks

Every reactive charm that uses charms.openstack and implements unit
testing needs to mock charmhelpers, as otherwise the tests blow up.
This patch uses the mocking of charmhelpers in charms.openstack so that
a charm layer can just import test_mocks and charmhelpers will be mocked
out along with setting up a default
charmhelpers.c.o.u.OPENSTACK_RELEASES so that when an OpenStackCharm()
derived charm class won't fail on definition.

Related-Bug: #1693017
(cherry-picked from openstack/charm-aodh commit d9c11f6525d22b7262e8a1203f08a6491043f151)

Change-Id: If67336436cfcb8a3ae6ae9549e0f0683f7f3fb22

commit_message:
api-tests: Common way to define required extensions

As some tests require extensions to be enabled on the server, this patch
introduces a new class attribute to the API base class. If any extension
defined in test class is not enabled on the server, then all tests in
the test class will be skipped.

Change-Id: I0629153f973daeb3bef3a6968360cbc2d427f9ad

This adds the ability to do version discovery with Cinder to
know if we can make requests at a specific microversion, like
3.27 in the case of creating/updating/deleting volume attachments.

We will use this to attempt an attachment_create at 3.27 when
attaching a volume to an instance and if 3.27 is not available
then the calling code will need to handle CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable
and fallback to the old style attachment flow.

For new style attachments, everything will be keyed off the
BlockDeviceMapping.attachment_id field being set if we successfully
created the attachment using 3.27, so the attachment_create method
is really the only one that should care about microversions initially.

Part of blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: I9b6ab9f71cc58d4514127f5ea61789f187487828
'}]
commit_message:
Use microversions for new style volume attachments

This adds the ability to do version discovery with Cinder to
know if we can make requests at a specific microversion, like
3.27 in the case of creating/updating/deleting volume attachments.

We will use this to attempt an attachment_create at 3.27 when
attaching a volume to an instance and if 3.27 is not available
then the calling code will need to handle CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable
and fallback to the old style attachment flow.

For new style attachments, everything will be keyed off the
BlockDeviceMapping.attachment_id field being set if we successfully
created the attachment using 3.27, so the attachment_create method
is really the only one that should care about microversions initially.

Part of blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: I9b6ab9f71cc58d4514127f5ea61789f187487828

We check the microversion when creating a new-style volume attachment.

If we use that API and create the volume attachment, we're going to
store the attachment id on the related BlockDeviceMapping object.

Code that's updating or deleting attachments for a BDM with the
attachment_id field set assumes that 3.27 is already available since
it was when the attachment was created, and therefore we don't need
to check the version again which saves us an extra GET / call to Cinder.

commit_message:
Skip microversion discovery check for update/delete volume attachments

We check the microversion when creating a new-style volume attachment.

If we use that API and create the volume attachment, we're going to
store the attachment id on the related BlockDeviceMapping object.

Code that's updating or deleting attachments for a BDM with the
attachment_id field set assumes that 3.27 is already available since
it was when the attachment was created, and therefore we don't need
to check the version again which saves us an extra GET / call to Cinder.

We also don't support rollbacks of the Cinder API, but if that did
happen and we requested 3.27 and it wasn't available, Cinder would
return a 406 error which would result in a compute fault.

Part of blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: I727fce7bbd84bcf58d7f1f91377fda35e36cbc7a

commit_message:
Use 3.27 microversion when creating new style volume attachments

Now that we have version discovery support we can explicitly
request 3.27 when creating a new-style volume attachment. If the
3.27 microversion is not available, CinderAPIVersionNotAvailable
will be raised back up to the caller, indicating an old-style
attachment needs to be made.

The same is done when updating or deleting new-style attachments.

A TODO is left inline for update and delete since we should be able
to assume that if we're updating or deleting a new style attachment,
which is keyed off the BlockDeviceMapping.attachment_id field, that
3.27 is available and we can save ourselves a GET / call to Cinder.

Part of blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: Icf8cda2c34dda9e7b56a586353842dd035b115cd

commit_message:
Ensure Swift Rings backup container and URLs

Swift Rings backup container and URLs for it are created only
during deploy but there is possibility of minor update or
change of deployment when they should be created. Adding them
in plan_management update_deployment_plan fixes these cases.

Closes-Bug: #1695778
Resolves: rhbz#1455616
Change-Id: Ifcedd54da5c74f12c863b8ec63679360673dd8f6

subject: Use Deployment actions for blacklist
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-07 18:06:54.000000000', 'files': ['puppet/compute-role.yaml', 'puppet/cephstorage-role.yaml', 'puppet/objectstorage-role.yaml', 'puppet/role.role.j2.yaml', 'puppet/blockstorage-role.yaml', 'puppet/controller-role.yaml'], 'message': 'Use Deployment actions for blacklist

Instead of using the Heat condition directly on the Deployment
resources, use it to set the action list to an empty list when the
server is blacklisted.

This has a couple advantages over the previous approach in that the
actual resources are not deleted and recreated when servers are added
and removed from the blacklist.

Recreating the resources can be problematic, as it would then force the
Deployments to re-run when a server is removed from the blacklist. That
is likely not always desirable, especially in the case of
NetworkDeloyment.

Additionally, you will still see the resources for a blacklisted server
in the stack, just with an empty set of actions. This has the benefit of
preserving the history of the previous time the Deployment was
triggered.

implements blueprint disable-deployments

Change-Id: I3d0263a6319ae4871b1ae11383ae838bd2540d36
'}]
commit_message:
Use Deployment actions for blacklist

Instead of using the Heat condition directly on the Deployment
resources, use it to set the action list to an empty list when the
server is blacklisted.

This has a couple advantages over the previous approach in that the
actual resources are not deleted and recreated when servers are added
and removed from the blacklist.

Recreating the resources can be problematic, as it would then force the
Deployments to re-run when a server is removed from the blacklist. That
is likely not always desirable, especially in the case of
NetworkDeloyment.

Additionally, you will still see the resources for a blacklisted server
in the stack, just with an empty set of actions. This has the benefit of
preserving the history of the previous time the Deployment was
triggered.

implements blueprint disable-deployments

Change-Id: I3d0263a6319ae4871b1ae11383ae838bd2540d36

subject: Fix problem that old releases do not know up-to-date release names
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-01 18:58:22.000000000', 'files': ['elements/debootstrap/root.d/08-debootstrap', 'releasenotes/notes/debootstrap_fix-unknown-releases-2ec2fcf043a716c6.yaml'], 'message': 'Fix problem that old releases do not know up-to-date release names

Old versions of Ubuntu or Debian do not know the names of the new
releases, example: debian-jessie has no idea about ubuntu-xenial.
This knowledge is needed to call debootstrap.

This patch adds a very small data set that provides a mapping between
release and script names.

Change-Id: Id25712166d2fae23d3cd5ceb72940cd321bb1340
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix problem that old releases do not know up-to-date release names

Old versions of Ubuntu or Debian do not know the names of the new
releases, example: debian-jessie has no idea about ubuntu-xenial.
This knowledge is needed to call debootstrap.

This patch adds a very small data set that provides a mapping between
release and script names.

Change-Id: Id25712166d2fae23d3cd5ceb72940cd321bb1340
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

This patch cleans up initialization of the block device's 'state'
dictionary.  It is not always created in the constructor and the

commit_message:
Refactor: Clean up state initialization

This patch cleans up initialization of the block device's 'state'
dictionary.  It is not always created in the constructor and the
entry '_loaded' flags if this state was loaded or not.

Change-Id: I5e7d3a55e86109fb7c3e79a6e3cf600381c73675
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

commit_message:
Refactor: Generalize parameters passed to plugins

The funtion 'create_graph()' is a generic function and does
not need to know which and how many parameters are passed
on to the plugin constructor.

This patch generalizes the parameter passing.

This patch is needed for upcoming patches that eliminate the globals
in block device handling.

Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

commit_message:
Refactor: Pass 'state' to plugin constructor

Currently the 'state' object is passed in to some methods of the
plugin object (only).
This patch passes in the state object already at construction
time of the plugin objects.  They have now the possibility to
use the state object directly during initialization (e.g. config
check).

Change-Id: I1cdc8b20373c5d582ea928cfd7334469ff36dbce
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

There were some global variables in these modules.  These
modules are now using the 'state' to store the internal
information.

(This finishes this patch stack.)

Change-Id: Ic3b805f9258128d5233b21ff25579c03487c7fcc
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
"}]
commit_message:
Refactor: Remove globals from block device mkfs and mount

There were some global variables in these modules.  These
modules are now using the 'state' to store the internal
information.

(This finishes this patch stack.)

Change-Id: Ic3b805f9258128d5233b21ff25579c03487c7fcc
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

commit_message:
Gather facts for run-bindep role

Because we want to use the package task, we need to know facts about
the host we are running on. Otherwise we get the following error:

  Could not detect which package manager to use. Try gathering facts
  or setting the "use" option.

Change-Id: I069f4025403e301af08137c19da1e5b35e21798d
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

subject: Allow service running state check through pgid
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-28 06:48:43.000000000', 'files': ['inc/upgrade'], 'message': "Allow service running state check through pgid

If service name doesn't match service process command line, state
detection falis in inc/upgrade:is_service_running.
Ironic-inspector-dhcp service for instance executes a dnsmasq process
that, although running, will not match its service name.

Suggested patch infers service running state through pid file in case
name matching fails.

Change-Id: I81f851ff1c9bb2f8722921db347d7f9d9262d952
"}]
commit_message:
Allow service running state check through pgid

If service name doesn't match service process command line, state
detection falis in inc/upgrade:is_service_running.
Ironic-inspector-dhcp service for instance executes a dnsmasq process
that, although running, will not match its service name.

Suggested patch infers service running state through pid file in case
name matching fails.

Change-Id: I81f851ff1c9bb2f8722921db347d7f9d9262d952

commit_message:
Permanent node cache

In order to reduce synchronization with ironic, the node_status_keep_time
service configuration option was deprecated and is silently ignored now.
This change will simplify the DHCP PXE boot filter maintenance and was
suggested in the Multiple filtering backends specification[1]

Partial-Bug: 1665666

[1]
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-inspector-specs/specs/multiple-pxe-filtering-backends.html

Change-Id: I72f7ab78064544f3e3a08dffce0700c8b7bd0535

[{'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-08 06:31:23.000000000', 'files': ['manila/rpc.py'], 'message': 'Use get_rpc_transport instead of get_transport

With the added get_rpc_transport() function in oslo.messaging [1]
and the recent version bump of oslo.messaging to 5.24.2, we can

cleaner.

commit_message:
Use get_rpc_transport instead of get_transport

With the added get_rpc_transport() function in oslo.messaging [1]
and the recent version bump of oslo.messaging to 5.24.2, we can
safely replace get_transport() with get_rpc_transport() which is much
cleaner.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/454194/

Related-Bug: #1680192
Change-Id: I6b2ee043048bc380c4dd75638817f8152617ce09

commit_message:
Use TEMPEST_REGEX in new keystone job

We need to set the regex in order for tempest to run with tox -eall
instead of tox -esmoke so that the plugin tests are actually included,
as well as to reduce the number of tests to just the plugin-specific
ones.

Change-Id: I438261e9d29c488067522eb7f50cc3c963753836

DevStack Ocata version and master use different default images

commit_message:
Fix grenade test related to encrypt volume/image

DevStack Ocata version and master use different default images
(Ocata:uec and master:qcow2), this will lead to tempest encrypt test
failure in grenade gate.

This patch hard-code default images in base version and will be
removed if devstack master and ocata patches are proposed.

Change-Id: I997c759fc026366fe48de9ac7e8c58941622c9cd
Co-Authored-By: Nam Nguyen Hoai <namnh@vn.fujitsu.com>

commit_message:
Change volume metadata not to use nested dicts

Ironic sets metadata to a volume when attaching and detaching. However,
Cinder doesn't accept metadata which consists of nested dictionaries.
This patch fixes the issue by passing metadata as string without
nested dictionaries.

Change-Id: Ibe0a752a923ff52526a7e04374e61c14f6c4f0b0
Partial-Bug: #1559691

subject: Make sync_routers chunking configurable
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 748, 'name': 'Armando Migliaccio', 'email': 'armamig@gmail.com', 'username': 'armando-migliaccio'}, {'_account_id': 1131, 'name': 'Brian Haley', 'email': 'haleyb.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-haley'}, {'_account_id': 1653, 'name': 'garyk', 'email': 'gkotton@vmware.com', 'username': 'garyk'}, {'_account_id': 7787, 'name': 'Kevin Benton', 'email': 'kevin@benton.pub', 'username': 'blak111'}, {'_account_id': 8871, 'name': 'Elastic Recheck', 'username': 'elasticrecheck'}, {'_account_id': 9732, 'name': 'Mellanox CI', 'email': 'mlnx-openstack-ci@dev.mellanox.co.il', 'username': 'mellanox', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 12021, 'name': 'Thomas Morin', 'email': 'tmmorin.orange@gmail.com', 'username': 'tmorin'}, {'_account_id': 12860, 'name': 'Dongcan Ye', 'email': 'yedongcan@yeah.net', 'username': 'yedongcan'}, {'_account_id': 15471, 'name': 'Nguyen Phuong An', 'email': 'annp.cs51@gmail.com', 'username': 'An-FVL'}, {'_account_id': 15752, 'name': 'Intel SR-IOV CI', 'email': 'sriov-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'sriovci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 16376, 'name': 'Intel NFV CI', 'email': 'openstack-nfv-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'intel-nfv-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 20330, 'name': 'Microsoft Hyper-V Networking CI', 'email': 'microsoft_neutron_ci@microsoft.com', 'username': 'microsoft_neutron_ci'}, {'_account_id': 24735, 'name': 'Alexandru Enache', 'email': 'lx@lxnch.ro', 'username': 'lxnch'}, {'_account_id': 26086, 'name': 'Cristian Calin', 'email': 'cristian.calin@orange.com', 'username': 'cristicalin'}]
revisions:
[{'number': 7, 'created': '2017-06-07 07:37:03.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/l3-agent-sync_routers_chunk-size-f359f5a3db248f6c.yaml', 'neutron/agent/l3/agent.py', 'neutron/conf/agent/l3/config.py'], 'message': 'Make sync_routers chunking configurable

This patch adds two extra configuration parameters to the l3_agent.ini
DEFAULT section, it is intended to allow an operator to configue
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE and SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE.

When the sync_routers call is made and a MessagingTimeout exception
occurs the agent will start decreasing the chunk size. The time it
takes to trigger MessagingTimeout depends on the ``rpc_response_timeout``
configuration parameter.

The current back-off logic implemented in ``neutron/common/rpc.py``
is to increase the rpc_response_timeout up to 10 times before resorting
to chunking. In effect this tries to scale up the RPC response timeout
window but still floods the server with calls that take several minutes
to process.

We observed that, in environments with multiple L3 agents (more than 6)
and a high number of routers per agent (more than 240), the RPC call to
sync_routes behaves exponentially instead of linearly.

The solution that the neutron-server advertises in the logs (to increase
the ``rpc_response_timeout``) defeats the point of chunking in the first
place and only increases the traffic outage instead of providing a
mitigation.

During our experiments we oserved that lower values for the
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE (tested with 64 and 32) allows the server
to respond within the timeout window and leads to a total recovery
within 3-5 minutes. While in theory this might increase the time needed
for the agent to fully recover due to trickling the list of routers
from the server, the observed behavior in practice is that it avoids
the unnecessary increase in ``rpc_response_timeout`` and completes
the agent recovery within and acceptable time window.

On large environments this patch gives an operator extra advanced
tunables to set while keeping the old defaults in place for everyone
else.

Closes-Bug: #1692971
DocImpact: add two advanced configuration options to the L3 agent
           to control the chunking behavior for the sync_routers
           RPC call

Change-Id: I70e5e1db709009a1c004a2ebe44b1ba595eba7b3
'}]
commit_message:
Make sync_routers chunking configurable

This patch adds two extra configuration parameters to the l3_agent.ini
DEFAULT section, it is intended to allow an operator to configue
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE and SYNC_ROUTERS_MIN_CHUNK_SIZE.

When the sync_routers call is made and a MessagingTimeout exception
occurs the agent will start decreasing the chunk size. The time it
takes to trigger MessagingTimeout depends on the ``rpc_response_timeout``
configuration parameter.

The current back-off logic implemented in ``neutron/common/rpc.py``
is to increase the rpc_response_timeout up to 10 times before resorting
to chunking. In effect this tries to scale up the RPC response timeout
window but still floods the server with calls that take several minutes
to process.

We observed that, in environments with multiple L3 agents (more than 6)
and a high number of routers per agent (more than 240), the RPC call to
sync_routes behaves exponentially instead of linearly.

The solution that the neutron-server advertises in the logs (to increase
the ``rpc_response_timeout``) defeats the point of chunking in the first
place and only increases the traffic outage instead of providing a
mitigation.

During our experiments we oserved that lower values for the
SYNC_ROUTERS_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE (tested with 64 and 32) allows the server
to respond within the timeout window and leads to a total recovery
within 3-5 minutes. While in theory this might increase the time needed
for the agent to fully recover due to trickling the list of routers
from the server, the observed behavior in practice is that it avoids
the unnecessary increase in ``rpc_response_timeout`` and completes
the agent recovery within and acceptable time window.

On large environments this patch gives an operator extra advanced
tunables to set while keeping the old defaults in place for everyone
else.

Closes-Bug: #1692971
DocImpact: add two advanced configuration options to the L3 agent
           to control the chunking behavior for the sync_routers
           RPC call

Change-Id: I70e5e1db709009a1c004a2ebe44b1ba595eba7b3

commit_message:
Standardize example role definitions

As we create new standard roles, we should include them from a single
location for ease of use and to reduce the duplication of the role
definitions elsewhere. This change adds a roles folder to the THT that
can be used with the new roles commands in python-tripleoclient by the
end user to generate a roles_data.yaml from a standard set of roles.

Depends-On: I326bae5bdee088e03aa89128d253612ef89e5c0c
Change-Id: Iad3e9b215c6f21ba761c8360bb7ed531e34520e6
Related-Blueprint: example-custom-role-environments

subject: Limit number of revert tombstone SSYNC requests
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1179, 'name': 'Clay Gerrard', 'email': 'clay.gerrard@gmail.com', 'username': 'clay-gerrard'}, {'_account_id': 4608, 'name': 'Kota Tsuyuzaki', 'email': 'bloodeagle40234@gmail.com', 'username': 'tsuyuzaki-kota'}, {'_account_id': 7233, 'name': 'Matthew Oliver', 'email': 'matt@oliver.net.au', 'username': 'mattoliverau'}, {'_account_id': 7847, 'name': 'Alistair Coles', 'email': 'alistairncoles@gmail.com', 'username': 'acoles'}, {'_account_id': 12261, 'name': 'Mahati', 'email': 'mahati.chamarthy@gmail.com', 'username': 'Mahati'}, {'_account_id': 13052, 'name': 'SwiftStack Cluster CI', 'email': 'openstack-ci@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'swiftstack-cluster-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 19554, 'name': 'Nam', 'email': 'namnh68@fsoft.com.vn', 'username': 'namnh'}]
revisions:
[{'number': 14, 'created': '2017-06-08 07:08:06.000000000', 'files': ['test/probe/test_reconstructor_revert.py', 'swift/obj/reconstructor.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_reconstructor.py'], 'message': "Limit number of revert tombstone SSYNC requests

Revert tombstone only parts try to talk to all primary nodes - this
fixes it to randomize selection within part_nodes. Corresponding probe
test is modified to reflect this change.

The primary improvement of this patch is the reconstuctor at a handoff
node is being able to delete local tombstones when it succeeds to sync
to less than all primary nodes. (Before this patch, it requires all
nodes are responsible for the REVERT requests)

The number of primary nodes to communicate with the reconstructor can be
in dicsussion more but, right now with this patch, it's (replicas - k + 1)
that is able to prevent stale read.

*BONUS*

- Fix mis-testsetting (was setting less replicas than ec_k + ec_m)
  for reconstructor ring in the unit test

Co-Authored-By: Kota Tsuyuzaki <tsuyuzaki.kota@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I05ce8fe75f1c4a7971cc8995b003df818b69b3c1
Closes-Bug: #1668857
"}]
commit_message:
Limit number of revert tombstone SSYNC requests

Revert tombstone only parts try to talk to all primary nodes - this
fixes it to randomize selection within part_nodes. Corresponding probe
test is modified to reflect this change.

The primary improvement of this patch is the reconstuctor at a handoff
node is being able to delete local tombstones when it succeeds to sync
to less than all primary nodes. (Before this patch, it requires all
nodes are responsible for the REVERT requests)

The number of primary nodes to communicate with the reconstructor can be
in dicsussion more but, right now with this patch, it's (replicas - k + 1)
that is able to prevent stale read.

*BONUS*

- Fix mis-testsetting (was setting less replicas than ec_k + ec_m)
  for reconstructor ring in the unit test

Co-Authored-By: Kota Tsuyuzaki <tsuyuzaki.kota@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I05ce8fe75f1c4a7971cc8995b003df818b69b3c1
Closes-Bug: #1668857

[{'number': 10, 'created': '2017-05-18 02:55:45.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/linuxbridge/agent/linuxbridge_neutron_agent.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/linuxbridge/agent/test_linuxbridge_neutron_agent.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/linuxbridge/mech_driver/test_mech_linuxbridge.py', 'releasenotes/notes/linuxbridge_cgroups-5943d85adace4de0.yaml', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/linuxbridge/mech_driver/mech_linuxbridge.py'], 'message': "Use vif_type='tap' for LinuxBridge for consistency

This adjusts the Linux Bridge mechanism driver to return
the 'tap' VIF type to Nova so the Linux Bridge agent is
responsible for plugging all ports into bridges.

This completely eliminates all of the work Nova was doing with
regard to bridges so we now have one consistent path how ports
(both compute and dhcp/l3) are connected into Linux Bridge
networks. Both Nova and the DHCP/L3 agents will now just create
a device and leave wiring to bridges to be completely the
responsibility of the L2 agent.

In order to preserve backwards compatibiliy with Ocata agents
that won't touch compute ports, we only report back vif_type='tap'
if the agent has a report_state value showing that it wires compute
ports.

This will also solve a longstanding bug (bug #1105488) that
is preventing Nova instances from using custom bridge mappings
since the agent will be guaranteed to be responsible for the
connection to the bridge.

Depends-On: I075595158d8f3b5a6811c4794aa7b91912940db5

Related-Bug: #1617447
Closes-Bug: #1673910
Closes-Bug: #1105488
Change-Id: I23c5faaeab69aede1fd038a36f4a0b8f928498ce
"}]
commit_message:
Use vif_type='tap' for LinuxBridge for consistency

This adjusts the Linux Bridge mechanism driver to return
the 'tap' VIF type to Nova so the Linux Bridge agent is
responsible for plugging all ports into bridges.

This completely eliminates all of the work Nova was doing with
regard to bridges so we now have one consistent path how ports
(both compute and dhcp/l3) are connected into Linux Bridge
networks. Both Nova and the DHCP/L3 agents will now just create
a device and leave wiring to bridges to be completely the
responsibility of the L2 agent.

In order to preserve backwards compatibiliy with Ocata agents
that won't touch compute ports, we only report back vif_type='tap'
if the agent has a report_state value showing that it wires compute
ports.

This will also solve a longstanding bug (bug #1105488) that
is preventing Nova instances from using custom bridge mappings
since the agent will be guaranteed to be responsible for the
connection to the bridge.

Depends-On: I075595158d8f3b5a6811c4794aa7b91912940db5

Related-Bug: #1617447
Closes-Bug: #1673910
Closes-Bug: #1105488
Change-Id: I23c5faaeab69aede1fd038a36f4a0b8f928498ce

commit_message:
Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3

html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: Ic4c7ee1d36ee58c31a91d094801683b6a5a47b9f
Closes-Bug:#1693670

commit_message:
Fix doc generation for Python3

Fix the Sphinx html_last_updated_fmt for Python3.
The html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Closes-Bug:#1693670

commit_message:
Move role policies to DocumentedRuleDefault

A new policy class was introduced that requires
additional parameters when defining policy objects.

This patch switches our role policy object to
the policy.DocumentedRuleDefault and fills the
required policy parameters as needed.

Co-Authored-By: Samriddhi Jain <j.samriddhi13@gmail.com>
Partially-Implements: bp policy-docs

commit_message:
Run minification and tree shaking on build

"npm run build" now builds an artifact optimized for production use.  The
removes dead code, and minizes the result.  The size of the bundle shrinks from
about 14MB to 2MB.

The previous build command is moved to "npm run build:dev".

Change-Id: I21430f06049c4eeeb4a66c7143da8c2919fb5a24
Closes-Bug: 1688610

commit_message:
Handle exising node file definition in full deploy script

full-deploy-ovb forces OPT_NODES value to a config under general_config
This change sets it only as default only if it wasn't already set.

commit_message:
Pre-upgrade: Check disk space

This patch adds a playbook to the pre-upgrade group that checks if the
undercloud disk has at least 10GB left for an upgrade.

The tasks from the existing undercloud-disk-space validation
(pre-deployment) are extracted into a separate file and reused.

Change-Id: I193fb6e9cbbe29726f312a273b30a1839da6e261
Implements: blueprint pre-upgrade-validations

subject: Fixing types.MethodType signature for Python 3.5
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1736, 'name': 'Ivan Kolodyazhny', 'email': 'e0ne@e0ne.info', 'username': 'e0ne'}, {'_account_id': 10273, 'name': 'Adam Harwell', 'email': 'flux.adam@gmail.com', 'username': 'rm_you'}, {'_account_id': 11628, 'name': 'Michael Johnson', 'email': 'johnsomor@gmail.com', 'username': 'johnsom'}, {'_account_id': 12826, 'name': 'Rob Cresswell', 'display_name': 'robcresswell', 'email': 'robert.cresswell@outlook.com', 'username': 'rob-cresswell'}, {'_account_id': 22623, 'name': 'Erik Olof Gunnar Andersson', 'email': 'eandersson@blizzard.com', 'username': 'eoandersson'}, {'_account_id': 25674, 'name': 'Jude Cross', 'email': 'jucross@blizzard.com', 'username': 'problem_v'}]
revisions:
[{'number': 5, 'created': '2017-06-07 19:32:12.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_dashboard/test/integration_tests/pages/navigation.py'], 'message': "Fixing types.MethodType signature for Python 3.5

The signature for MethodType has changed in Python 3,
and the current implementation won't work, to fix this
we are replacing it with the py 2/3 compatible
python-six equivalent, six.create_unbound_method.
http://six.readthedocs.io/#six.create_unbound_method

This is causing the Python 3.5 tests to fail for the
octavia-dashboard when importing the navigation.py
file, throwing the following error.
> TypeError: method expected 2 arguments, got 3

The following review to fix the gate for the
octavia-dashboard is depending on this patch.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/471611/

This can also be reproduced by simply executing
navigation.py using Python 3.5.
> python3.5 nagivation.py

Change-Id: Iebca15ae962a1aa0825c6ba6d482206531726696
"}]
commit_message:
Fixing types.MethodType signature for Python 3.5

The signature for MethodType has changed in Python 3,
and the current implementation won't work, to fix this
we are replacing it with the py 2/3 compatible
python-six equivalent, six.create_unbound_method.
http://six.readthedocs.io/#six.create_unbound_method

This is causing the Python 3.5 tests to fail for the
octavia-dashboard when importing the navigation.py
file, throwing the following error.
> TypeError: method expected 2 arguments, got 3

The following review to fix the gate for the
octavia-dashboard is depending on this patch.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/471611/

This can also be reproduced by simply executing
navigation.py using Python 3.5.
> python3.5 nagivation.py

Change-Id: Iebca15ae962a1aa0825c6ba6d482206531726696

subject: [ci][samples] Reduce redundant authentications
revisions:
[{'number': 3, 'created': '2017-06-08 12:19:58.000000000', 'files': ['tests/functional/test_task_samples.py'], 'message': '[ci][samples] Reduce redundant authentications

While validating a single sample, rally obtains a new deployment object
from the database. Since we have hundreds of samples, validation of each
single sample performs redundant steps, such as authentication.

This patch mocks obtaining deployment objects with special method
get_credentials_for with cache mechanism.

Change-Id: I51d6e3aa7897c100d114f978883cd4526b0222ba
'}]
commit_message:
[ci][samples] Reduce redundant authentications

While validating a single sample, rally obtains a new deployment object
from the database. Since we have hundreds of samples, validation of each
single sample performs redundant steps, such as authentication.

This patch mocks obtaining deployment objects with special method
get_credentials_for with cache mechanism.

Change-Id: I51d6e3aa7897c100d114f978883cd4526b0222ba

subject: Switch instack-undercloud to cycle-with-intermediary
revisions:
[{'number': 3, 'created': '2017-06-07 11:52:21.000000000', 'files': ['deliverables/pike/instack-undercloud.yaml'], 'message': "Switch instack-undercloud to cycle-with-intermediary

This is required for If07880e4bc25cffe485704772d64f62288a1a53d so
we can stop using the bash layer of indirection between tripleoclient
and instack-undercloud.  In order to do that, we need to be able to
depend on instack-undercloud directly, but it can't go into g-r
with its current release model.  This release model better reflects
the intended use of instack-undercloud as a library instead of a
CLI in its own right.

Change-Id: I42235d13acf617f3bcbf22cd737ebf21378902b4
"}]
commit_message:
Switch instack-undercloud to cycle-with-intermediary

This is required for If07880e4bc25cffe485704772d64f62288a1a53d so
we can stop using the bash layer of indirection between tripleoclient
and instack-undercloud.  In order to do that, we need to be able to
depend on instack-undercloud directly, but it can't go into g-r
with its current release model.  This release model better reflects
the intended use of instack-undercloud as a library instead of a
CLI in its own right.

Change-Id: I42235d13acf617f3bcbf22cd737ebf21378902b4

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-08 13:47:21.000000000', 'files': ['shade/_adapter.py', 'shade/operatorcloud.py', 'shade/openstackcloud.py'], 'message': "Don't remove top-container element for volume REST API calls

This is a first step in the process of removing the logic
from the shade.Adapter that removes top-container element from
the REST PAI response. The goal is to simplify the logic and
move it into the REST API calls.

Change-Id: I885ba0c8d1df8c6f33bd3e2e92d052a1614a917f
Signed-off-by: Rosario Di Somma <rosario.disomma@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Don't remove top-container element for volume REST API calls

This is a first step in the process of removing the logic
from the shade.Adapter that removes top-container element from
the REST PAI response. The goal is to simplify the logic and
move it into the REST API calls.

Change-Id: I885ba0c8d1df8c6f33bd3e2e92d052a1614a917f
Signed-off-by: Rosario Di Somma <rosario.disomma@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Use get_discovery from keystoneauth

If we use the get_discovery call, we'll re-use the keystoneauth cache.
This removes the last stupid extra discovery call.

While doing this, noticed the dns version discovery was wrong, but we
weren't noticing because adapter magic. Fix it.

Change-Id: I01d07554d094fffd498f21a9291710c8eb0041f6

commit_message:
Require python-novaclient >= 9.0.0

This introduces the new global_request_id parameter which is needed
for cross service request ids. Make this the minimum version so that
projects can depend on this parameter existing in the constructor.

Change-Id: I5b247f75edeea9da50fe524eadf5f9a2c626d665

commit_message:
Fix condition_map type checking for strings

The explit type checking in condition_match is broken at the very
least for strings. For now, go ahead and explicitly handle the
string case. In the future, we should evaluate why that code block
was added in the first place.

Change-Id: I730503e655ece8e862874679f00a5980a3d0e7a2

The spec for nova's use of the cinder v3 api calls for migrate
to create a new attachment on the destination host, and rollback
to the old attachment on a failure.

I8acc30502ba6e9ff061ca2d80fa73f6da2be7cef

To enable that, we need a place to store the old attachment_id

commit_message:
objects: Add old_attachment_id to BlockDeviceMapping

The spec for nova's use of the cinder v3 api calls for migrate
to create a new attachment on the destination host, and rollback
to the old attachment on a failure.

I8acc30502ba6e9ff061ca2d80fa73f6da2be7cef

To enable that, we need a place to store the old attachment_id
in the bdm. This updates the bdm with this new old_attachment_id
field.

Change-Id: Ib81f54486a68a8142f0833bb7ec5dc058549cff1
Implements: blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

[{'number': 6, 'created': '2017-06-07 20:44:21.000000000', 'files': ['ovsdbapp/schema/open_vswitch/impl_idl.py', 'ovsdbapp/tests/unit/test_api.py', 'ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/command.py', 'ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py', 'ovsdbapp/schema/open_vswitch/api.py', 'ovsdbapp/api.py', 'ovsdbapp/schema/open_vswitch/commands.py'], 'message': "Make schema-agnostic db commands part of base API

The various OVSDB schemas and CLI utils all support the same
basic DB operations: get/set/add/clear/destroy/find/list. This
patch requires all backend implementations to support these ops
and will allow any schema implementations sharing a backend to
share those operations.

Since the implementations are already subclassing the
backend-agnostic API definitions and the backend db ops are
backend-specific and schema-agnostic partial implementations
themselves, the options for implementing this were mixins or
composition. This patch chooses mixins despite their
(usually deserved) bad repution. The Backend operations all
require access to the class they are mixed into (or would
be composed into). In the end, composition ended up being
more work for a less useful result.

An implementation would choose the Idl backend ops like:
from ovsdbapp.backend import ovs_idl

class MyOVSIdlImpl(ovs_idl.Backend, api.API):

If any implementation doesn't specify a backend (like Neutron's
CLI implementation), then it must define the Backend db_*
methods in the implementation itself (like Neutron's CLI
implementation already does). This means this change should be
backward-compatible with projects using ovsdbapp.

Change-Id: Iec53837de1205ab48b16ac7dc9b6eebdd8c4c400
"}]
commit_message:
Make schema-agnostic db commands part of base API

The various OVSDB schemas and CLI utils all support the same
basic DB operations: get/set/add/clear/destroy/find/list. This
patch requires all backend implementations to support these ops
and will allow any schema implementations sharing a backend to
share those operations.

Since the implementations are already subclassing the
backend-agnostic API definitions and the backend db ops are
backend-specific and schema-agnostic partial implementations
themselves, the options for implementing this were mixins or
composition. This patch chooses mixins despite their
(usually deserved) bad repution. The Backend operations all
require access to the class they are mixed into (or would
be composed into). In the end, composition ended up being
more work for a less useful result.

An implementation would choose the Idl backend ops like:
from ovsdbapp.backend import ovs_idl

class MyOVSIdlImpl(ovs_idl.Backend, api.API):

If any implementation doesn't specify a backend (like Neutron's
CLI implementation), then it must define the Backend db_*
methods in the implementation itself (like Neutron's CLI
implementation already does). This means this change should be
backward-compatible with projects using ovsdbapp.

Change-Id: Iec53837de1205ab48b16ac7dc9b6eebdd8c4c400

subject: Better handle key=value pair not being key=value
revisions:
[{'number': 3, 'created': '2017-06-02 00:41:23.000000000', 'files': ['novaclient/v2/shell.py', 'novaclient/tests/unit/v2/test_shell.py'], 'message': "Better handle key=value pair not being key=value

Previously, --block-device and --ephemeral would error out with an
insctrutable (to the user) error message if one of the key=value pair
it expects wasn't actually key=value, for instance:

nova --block-device 995abd81-2626-413c-9af6-51f105fab214,tag=foo \
     --image CirrOS --flavor custom my_instance

ValueError: dictionary update sequence element #0 has length 1; 2 is
required

This patch makes the error message clearer.

Change-Id: I2dd5dd805df2b0382b015dc625205119d7d0b03b
"}]
commit_message:
Better handle key=value pair not being key=value

Previously, --block-device and --ephemeral would error out with an
insctrutable (to the user) error message if one of the key=value pair
it expects wasn't actually key=value, for instance:

nova --block-device 995abd81-2626-413c-9af6-51f105fab214,tag=foo \
     --image CirrOS --flavor custom my_instance

ValueError: dictionary update sequence element #0 has length 1; 2 is
required

This patch makes the error message clearer.

Change-Id: I2dd5dd805df2b0382b015dc625205119d7d0b03b

This spec proposes to introduce a new API object 'capsule' to Zun.
Capsule represents a tightly coupled unit of containers and other
resources like sandbox. The containers in a capsule work closely

Part of blueprint introduce-compose

commit_message:
Introduce container composition

This spec proposes to introduce a new API object 'capsule' to Zun.
Capsule represents a tightly coupled unit of containers and other
resources like sandbox. The containers in a capsule work closely
together to form a cohesive unit of service.

Part of blueprint introduce-compose

Co-authored-by: Kevin Zhao <kevin.zhao@linaro.org>
Change-Id: I608d4c7c3141d9529202efafe149f9e74f5fcc4f

commit_message:
Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3.

html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: Ie954a0fb0a0eaf6e23a1bf9a846c4fd665606acc
Closes-Bug:#1693670

both oslo.db and Nova, so don't need set its default value.

0a1bae9859079fb21a03716be947c5f1da6db0a2/oslo_db/options.py#L17

commit_message:
[ci][samples] Try to speed up checking samples

The validation of all samples takes too much time. It is an attempt to
speed up the check by using broker pattern (validate several samples in
parallel).

commit_message:
Don't pass argument sqlite_db in method set_defaults

Config option sqlite_db is deprecated for removal[1], and isn't used in
both oslo.db and Nova, so don't need set its default value.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/\
0a1bae9859079fb21a03716be947c5f1da6db0a2/oslo_db/options.py#L17

Change-Id: I4cd84f1750ed7cf6c595cec6d6f52b79c73c311b

[{'number': 9, 'created': '2017-06-06 10:11:34.000000000', 'files': ['manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/base.py', 'manila/api/v2/share_group_types.py', 'manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/admin/test_share_group_types_negative.py', 'manila/tests/api/v2/test_share_group_types.py'], 'message': '[Share Groups] Fix creation of share group types with wrong specs values

Closes-Bug: #1673446
'}]
commit_message:
[Share Groups] Fix creation of share group types with wrong specs values

If we provide some other type than None or dict as group specs
creating share group type, then we get error 500 caused by unhandled
exception. So, avoid it by explicitly checking type of provided group
specs.

Change-Id: I81312617f37a8f559b3c9201b03cf8be31761365
Closes-Bug: #1673446

subject: Fix the depends-on gating for basic.sh
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-08 11:31:33.000000000', 'files': ['ci-scripts/basic.sh', 'ci-scripts/include-gate-changes.sh'], 'message': "Fix the depends-on gating for basic.sh

The gate-quickstart role uninstalls the 'tripleo-quickstart-extras'
package from the virtual env if it finds a change for it, while
modifying the quickstart-extras-requirements.txt to get it reinstalled
from the locally checked out version with the next run. That run
requires the --bootstrap option to rerun the pip commands and reinstall.
This was missing from basic.sh.

The previous workaround is not needed which manually installed the
repo. Removing the workaround fixes a bug that broke devmode.sh.

Closes-bug: #1696532
Change-Id: I65a1b286a03e9f039c75b930e3eca5ceedeb0fd6
"}]
commit_message:
Fix the depends-on gating for basic.sh

The gate-quickstart role uninstalls the 'tripleo-quickstart-extras'
package from the virtual env if it finds a change for it, while
modifying the quickstart-extras-requirements.txt to get it reinstalled
from the locally checked out version with the next run. That run
requires the --bootstrap option to rerun the pip commands and reinstall.
This was missing from basic.sh.

The previous workaround is not needed which manually installed the
repo. Removing the workaround fixes a bug that broke devmode.sh.

Closes-bug: #1696532
Change-Id: I65a1b286a03e9f039c75b930e3eca5ceedeb0fd6
